questiontext.text: Determine the probability that the standard normal variable is less than -0.72. In other words, evaluate P(Z<−0.72)P(Z < -0.72).

generalfeedback.text:
The numbers that satisfy Z<−0.72Z<-0.72 are on the left side of a number line (toward −∞-\infty). The probability equals a left area under the density curve.


By using the z-table, we find the appropriate probability. P(Z<−0.72)=0.2358P(Z<-0.72)=0.2358

It might help to visualize with a spinner:


Using a spreadsheet:

=NORM.DIST(-0.72,0,1,TRUE)

Using R:

pnorm(-0.72)

questiontext.text: Determine the probability that the standard normal variable is more than 0.43. In other words, evaluate P(Z>0.43)P(Z > 0.43).

generalfeedback.text:
First, you need to identify that we are looking for a right area. This is because large values of ZZ satisfy Z>0.43Z>0.43.


By using the z-table, we find the left area (even though we eventually want the right area).

P(Z<0.43)=0.6664P(Z<0.43)=0.6664

We use the rule of compliments to determine the right area.

P(Z>0.43)=1−P(Z<0.43)=1−0.6664=0.3336\begin{aligned} P(Z > 0.43) &= 1-P(Z < 0.43) \\ &= 1-0.6664 \\ &= 0.3336 \end{aligned}

Method 2: You might also recognize that the normal distribution is symmetric. Thus,

P(Z>0.43)=P(Z<−0.43)=0.3336\begin{aligned} P(Z > 0.43) &= P(Z < -0.43) \\ &= 0.3336 \end{aligned}

Method 3: It often helps to draw a picture.


It might help to visualize with a spinner:


Using a spreadsheet:

=1-NORM.DIST(0.43,0,1,TRUE)

Using R:

1-pnorm(0.43)

questiontext.text: Determine the probability that the standard normal variable is between -0.04 and 0.88. In other words, evaluate P(−0.04<Z<0.88)P(-0.04 < Z < 0.88).

generalfeedback.text:
Start with a sketch.


We take a difference of areas. P(−0.04<Z<0.88)=P(Z<0.88)−P(Z<−0.04)=0.8106−0.484=0.3266\begin{aligned} P(-0.04<Z<0.88) &= P(Z<0.88) - P(Z<-0.04) \\ &= 0.8106 - 0.484 \\ &= 0.3266 \end{aligned}



In a spreadsheet, you could use the NORM.DIST() function.

=NORM.DIST(0.88,0,1,TRUE) - NORM.DIST(-0.04,0,1,TRUE)

In R, you could use the pnorm function.

pnorm(0.88) - pnorm(-0.04)

questiontext.text: Determine the probability that the absolute standard normal variable is less than 1.15. In other words, evaluate P(|Z|<1.15)P\left(|Z| < 1.15\right).

generalfeedback.text:
First, you need to identify that we are looking for a central area. This is because zz-scores near 0 satisfy |Z|<1.15|Z|<1.15, while zz-scores far from 0 (either positive or negative) do not satisfy the inequality.

Start with a sketch.


Remember, the entire area is always 1. Most z-tables only provide left areas, so three methods are shown to get the central area from a left-area (cumulative probability) table.

Method 1: First find the area of the left tail. P(Z<−1.15)=0.1251P(Z<-1.15) = 0.1251 Recognize normal distributions are symmetric, so we also know the area of the right tail. P(Z>1.15)=0.1251P(Z>1.15) = 0.1251 The three areas add to 1. P(|Z|<1.15)=1−P(Z<−1.15)−P(Z>1.15)=1−0.1251−0.1251=0.7498\begin{aligned} P\left(|Z|<1.15\right) &= 1-P(Z<-1.15)-P(Z>1.15) \\ &= 1 - 0.1251 - 0.1251 \\ &= 0.7498 \end{aligned}

This technique can be summarized with the following formula: P(|Z|<z)=1−2⋅P(Z<−z)P\left(|Z|<z\right) = 1-2\cdot P(Z<-z) assuming z>0z>0.

So, in our case (when z=1.15z=1.15), P(|Z|<1.15)=1−2⋅P(Z<−1.15)=1−2⋅0.1251=0.7498\begin{aligned} P\left(|Z|<1.15\right) &= 1-2\cdot P(Z<-1.15) \\ &= 1-2\cdot0.1251 \\ &= 0.7498 \end{aligned}

This method is shown graphically:


Method 2: You can also find half of the central area and then double it. P(|Z|<z)=2⋅[P(Z<z)−0.5]=2⋅[0.8749−0.5]=2⋅[0.3749]=0.7498\begin{aligned} P\left(|Z|<z\right) &= 2\cdot\left[ P(Z<z)-0.5\right] \\ &= 2\cdot\left[ 0.8749-0.5\right] \\ &= 2\cdot\left[ 0.3749\right] \\ &= 0.7498 \end{aligned}

This method is shown graphically:


Method 3: You can also calculate the central area with a difference of two left areas.

P(|Z|<1.15)=P(Z<1.15)−P(Z<−1.15)=0.8749−0.1251=0.7498\begin{aligned} P\left(|Z|<1.15\right) &= P(Z<1.15)-P(Z<-1.15)\\ &= 0.8749-0.1251 \\ &= 0.7498 \end{aligned}


It might be helpful to visualize with a spinner.


In a spreadsheet, you could use the NORM.DIST() function.

=NORM.DIST(1.15,0,1,TRUE) - NORM.DIST(-1.15,0,1,TRUE)

In R, you could use the pnorm function.

pnorm(1.15) - pnorm(-1.15)

questiontext.text: Determine the probability that the absolute standard normal variable is more than 1.24. In other words, evaluate P(|Z|>1.24)P\left(|Z| > 1.24\right).

generalfeedback.text:
First, you need to identify that we are looking for a two-tail area (the sum of the left and right tails). This is because zz-scores far from 0 satisfy |Z|>1.24|Z|>1.24, while zz-scores near 0 do not satisfy the inequality.

Start with a sketch.


Remember, the entire area is always 1. Most z-tables only provides left areas, so three methods are shown to get the two-tail area from a left-area (cumulative probability) table.

Method 1: First find the area of the left tail. P(Z<−1.24)=0.1075P(Z<-1.24) = 0.1075 Recognize normal distributions are symmetric, so we also know the area of the right tail. P(Z>1.24)=0.1075P(Z>1.24) = 0.1075 The two areas add to our desired two-tail area. P(|Z|>1.24)=P(Z<−1.24)+P(Z>1.24)=0.1075+0.1075=0.215\begin{aligned} P\left(|Z|>1.24\right) &= P(Z<-1.24)+P(Z>1.24) \\ &= 0.1075 + 0.1075 \\ &= 0.215 \end{aligned}

This technique can be summarized with the following formula: P(|Z|>z)=2⋅P(Z<−z)P\left(|Z|>z\right) = 2\cdot P(Z<-z) assuming z>0z>0.

So, in our case (when z=1.24z=1.24), P(|Z|<1.24)=2⋅P(Z<−1.24)=2⋅0.1075=0.215\begin{aligned} P\left(|Z|<1.24\right) &= 2\cdot P(Z<-1.24) \\ &= 2\cdot0.1075 \\ &= 0.215 \end{aligned}

This method is shown graphically:


Notice we need to add both tails.

Method 2: You can achieve the same result by using the following formula: P(|Z|>z)=2⋅[1−P(Z<z)]P\left(|Z|>z\right) = 2\cdot\left[1-P(Z<z) \right] So, P(|Z|>1.24)=2⋅[1−P(Z<1.24)]=2⋅[1−0.8925]=2⋅0.1075=0.215\begin{aligned} P\left(|Z|>1.24\right) &= 2\cdot\left[1-P(Z<1.24) \right] \\ &= 2\cdot\left[1-0.8925\right] \\ &= 2\cdot0.1075\\ &= 0.215 \end{aligned}

It might be helpful to visualize with a spinner.


In a spreadsheet, you could use the NORM.DIST() function.

=2*NORM.DIST(-1.24,0,1,TRUE)

In R, you could use the pnorm function.

2*pnorm(-1.24)
